qas.question: What element is used in glass to keep it from becoming too hot?
What property of thorium oxide has caused it to no longer be used in eyeglasses?
What is another name for lead glass?
What is the benefit of thorium oxide in addition to its refractive index?
What element is used in glass to help it from becoming more reflective?
How does barium affect movie filters?
What property of thorium oxide has caused it to no longer be used in projectors?
What is another name for cerium oxide?
What is the benefit of heat absorbing filters in addition to its refractive index?

context: Most common glass contains other ingredients to change its properties. Lead glass or <a3_0><b8_0>flint glass<b8_0/><a3_0/> is more 'brilliant' because the increased refractive index causes noticeably more specular reflection and increased optical dispersion. Adding barium also <a1_0><b6_0>increases the refractive index<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Thorium oxide gives glass a high refractive index and <a4_0><b9_0>low dispersion<b9_0/><a4_0/> and was formerly used in producing high-quality lenses, but due to its <a2_0><b7_0>radioactivity<b7_0/><a2_0/> has been replaced by lanthanum oxide in modern eyeglasses.[citation needed] <a0_0><b5_0>Iron<b5_0/><a0_0/> can be incorporated into glass to absorb infrared energy, for example in heat absorbing filters for movie projectors, while cerium(IV) oxide can be used for glass that absorbs UV wavelengths.
